title: The Language of Moral Reasoning
description: Grammatical structures for expressing ethical arguments and obligations

sections.title: Deontic Modality
sections.explanation: Expressing obligation, permission, and prohibition in moral discourse.

patterns.example: One ought to keep one's promises.
patterns.note: 'Ought' is preferred in philosophical discourse over 'should'

patterns.example: A person may defend themselves against aggression.
patterns.note: Distinguishes what is allowed from what is required

patterns.example: One must not use persons merely as means.
While not obligated to do so, donating a kidney would be praiseworthy.

sections.title: Conditional Structures in Ethics
sections.explanation: Expressing hypothetical imperatives and conditional duties.

patterns.structure: If one wants X, one ought to Y
patterns.example: If you want to be trusted, you ought to be honest.
patterns.contrast: Differs from categorical imperative, which applies unconditionally

patterns.structure: Other things being equal / In the absence of countervailing considerations
patterns.example: Other things being equal, one ought to tell the truth.

patterns.structure: X is prima facie wrong / At first glance, X is...
patterns.example: Lying is prima facie wrong, but may be justified in extreme circumstances.

sections.title: Logical Connectors in Ethical Argument
sections.explanation: Structures for building and analyzing moral arguments.

connectors.example: An action is right if and only if it maximizes utility.
Lying violates the categorical imperative. Therefore, lying is wrong.
The principle entails that we must never treat persons merely as means.
Granted that pleasure is the only intrinsic good, utilitarianism follows.

sections.title: Expressing Moral Intuitions and Counterexamples
sections.explanation: Structures for presenting intuitive judgments and testing theories.

expressions: The case elicits the intuition that...
The theory implies that X, which seems absurd.
This commits one to the counterintuitive position that...
This apparent counterexample can be accommodated by...
The intuition in this case may be unreliable because...
A sufficiently refined version of the theory would hold that...

exercises.instruction: Identify the type of deontic claim
exercises.sentence: While not required, donating to charity would be morally admirable.

exercises.instruction: Express as a prima facie duty
exercises.original: Telling the truth is always obligatory.
exercises.answer: Telling the truth is prima facie obligatory, though it may be overridden by weightier considerations.

exercises.instruction: Construct a counterexample to this principle
exercises.principle: The consequences of an action determine its moral status.
exercises.answer: Consider a case where two agents act identically but with different outcomes due to luck. If consequences alone matter, then one acted wrongly and the other rightly, despite identical intentions and actions. Yet intuitively, they seem equally blameworthy or praiseworthy.
